title: Global Economic Outlook: February 2026
content: This February 2026 report from S&P Global analyzes the global economic outlook, highlighting the impact of geopolitical uncertainty on markets despite resilient economic conditions suggested by PMI data. It details key changes in their forecast, including higher real GDP growth projections for the US, India, and the eurozone, leading to an increased global growth forecast of 2.9% for 2026. The report also addresses consumer price inflation expectations, noting projected moderations driven by oil prices and easing underlying pressures, and discusses factors influencing US dollar depreciation an

title: Banco de Chile Stock: Quiet Latin Bank With U.S. Dollar Upside?
content: Banco de Chile’s stock has been sliding under Wall Street’s radar, even as dollar earnings look resilient and dividends stay rich. Here is what recent results and Chilean rate cuts could mean for U.S. income-focused investors now. Bottom line: If you are a U.S. investor hunting for bank exposure outside the crowded U.S. mega-cap names, Banco de Chile may deserve a fresh look. The Chilean lender is profitable, pays an above-average dividend, and gives you diversified Latin American exposure in U.S. dollars via its NYSE-listed ADR (BCH) – but its upside is tightly linked to Chile’s interest-rate cycle and the peso. You are not going to see Banco de Chile trending like the big U.S. money-center banks. Yet the combination of disciplined capital ratios, a conservative credit book, and a shareholder-friendly dividend policy has made it a quiet compounder for patient investors who can live with emerging-market volatility. More about the company What investors need to know now: how recent earnings, Chile’s aggressive interest-rate cuts, and a softer peso could reshape Banco de Chile’s dollar returns over the next 6–18 months. Banco de Chile is one of the country’s largest and most systemically important banks, focused on retail, SME, and corporate lending, plus treasury services. For U.S. investors, exposure typically comes through the BCH ADR listed on the NYSE, which represents local shares and trades in U.S. dollars. Over the past year, BCH has largely tracked a basket of Chilean financials and the performance of the Chilean peso (CLP) versus the U.S. dollar. When local rates were elevated, net interest margins fattened; as the Chilean central bank cut rates to support growth, margins normalized and the stock de?rated from peak levels. The company’s own investor materials stress a conservative risk culture: high capitalization, solid liquidity, and a well-seasoned retail loan book. This profile tends to hold up better during domestic slowdowns but leaves less explosive upside in boom times versus higher-beta Latin American peers. The following table summarizes the core aspects U.S. investors usually watch for a Latin American bank like Banco de Chile. Figures are indicative and should be cross-checked in the latest filings and earnings presentation before making decisions. The Chilean central bank has been one of the more proactive in Latin America in cutting interest rates after a period of high inflation. For Banco de Chile, this has two main implications. For U.S. investors, the critical question is whether the normalization of margins will be offset by improved loan growth and lower credit losses. Historically, Banco de Chile has managed such transitions reasonably well compared with more aggressive peers, but the adjustment typically weighs on valuation multiples in the near term. Banco de Chile’s ADR offers three things U.S. investors often look for when stepping outside domestic banks: However, those benefits come with emerging-market risks that U.S. investors must respect: currency swings, political noise, regulatory shifts, and lower trading liquidity than major U.S. bank stocks. Position sizing and time horizon are crucial. BCH typically shows only a moderate correlation with the S&P 500 and U.S. financial ETFs such as XLF or KBE. During global risk?off episodes, all risk assets tend to sell off together, but in normal periods, local Chilean factors drive a larger share of the price action. That means Banco de Chile can function as a diversifier in a U.S.-heavy portfolio, but it will not be immune to broad sentiment shifts around banks or emerging markets. U.S. treasury yields, the dollar index (DXY), and global commodity prices can all indirectly influence the stock. Recent earnings from major Chilean banks, including Banco de Chile, have shown a pattern common to many global lenders coming off a period of high rates: strong capital and solid credit quality, but normalized profitability as net interest margins retreat from unusual highs. On recent calls and in investor presentations, management has tended to emphasize: If Chile’s economy stabilizes and disinflation continues, that backdrop could support a more predictable earnings profile , albeit at lower margins than during the peak rate period. For investors, this transition usually favors longer-term income strategies over short-term trading. For any U.S. holder of Banco de Chile’s ADR, the Chilean peso is effectively a second layer of risk. Strong local earnings can be more than offset by a weaker CLP, while even flat profits can deliver solid dollar returns if the peso appreciates. For U.S. investors, the cleanest approach is to treat BCH as a combined bank plus FX trade : you are betting both on Banco de Chile’s execution and on a reasonably constructive medium-term view of the peso. Coverage of Banco de Chile by major Wall Street houses is more limited than that of large U.S. banks, but several global and regional brokers regularly update their views based on earnings, macro data, and Chilean policy moves. Recent analyst commentary from mainstream financial-data platforms indicates a generally neutral to moderately constructive stance on the stock, with the following key themes: Across the analyst spectrum, you are likely to see a blend of "Hold" and selective "Buy" ratings , often with target prices implying mid?single to low double?digit percentage upside from recent trading levels, before FX effects. Very few houses position it as a high?beta recovery play; instead, they frame it as a relatively defensive Latin American bank with income appeal. As always, investors should not rely on any single source. It is essential to cross?check analyst estimates, company guidance, and your own macro view on Chile and the peso before sizing a position. Before taking action, review Banco de Chile’s latest annual report, quarterly earnings presentations, and risk disclosures on its investor-relations page. These documents provide the most up?to?date, audited financial data and management commentary. Deep dive into Banco de Chile investor materials Want to see what the market is saying? Check out real opinions here: Disclosure: This article is for informational purposes only and does not constitute investment advice, an offer, or a solicitation to buy or sell any security. Always perform your own due diligence and consult a registered financial advisor before investing in foreign securities. Emotionale Kurzschlussreaktionen auf unruhige Märkte kosten dich bares Geld. title: Forex Signals Feb 19: Walmart (WMT), Alibaba, Rio Tinto and Gold Fields Earnings Preview
content: Large companies in the retail, e-commerce, and global mining industries are releasing their earnings today, including Walmart Inc., Alibaba Group Holding Limited, Rio Tinto Group, and Gold Fields Limited. The U.S. dollar moved broadly higher yesterday, supported by a steady rise in Treasury yields and a series of better-than-expected economic releases. Momentum built throughout the session as investors digested fresh data alongside the latest FOMC minutes, reinforcing expectations that U.S. monetary policy will remain restrictive for longer. December durable goods orders declined 1.4%, but the drop was less severe than the expected 2.0% contraction. Broader data painted a firmer picture. Housing starts and building permits improved, industrial production rose 0.7% versus 0.4% expected, and manufacturing output climbed 0.6%, also beating forecasts. Collectively, the data suggested economic resilience despite tighter financial conditions. The January FOMC minutes leaned hawkish overall. While two officials dissented in favor of a 25-basis-point rate cut, most participants supported holding rates steady at 3.5%–3.75%. The minutes emphasized caution, with policymakers signaling little urgency to ease. Officials acknowledged the possibility of “two-sided” policy guidance, meaning rates could move in either direction if inflation progress stalls. Inflation forecasts were nudged slightly higher, and staff projections showed GDP running above potential growth through 2028. Policymakers warned that the path back to 2% inflation may be slower and more uneven, reinforcing the “higher for longer” narrative. Adding to inflation concerns, crude oil surged $2.90 (+4.66%) to $65.22, its largest Monday gain since June 17, amid escalating geopolitical tensions involving Iran. Treasury yields rose across the curve, with the 10-year reaching 4.0865%. Despite higher yields, equities extended gains. The Dow rose 0.28%, the S&P 500 advanced 0.56%, and the Nasdaq gained 0.70%, marking its second consecutive positive session. Today’s earnings lineup spans defensive retail, Chinese technology, and global mining—offering a broad read on consumer health, commodity demand, and global economic momentum. Walmart may provide insight into U.S. spending resilience, Alibaba into China’s recovery trajectory, while Rio Tinto and Gold Fields will reflect trends in industrial metals and precious commodities. Key question: Can Walmart sustain earnings momentum while managing cost pressures and competitive pricing? Given macro uncertainty and valuation sensitivity across sectors, forward guidance could matter more than headline earnings beats. Market reaction is likely to hinge not only on results, but on management confidence about demand, margins and capital discipline in the quarters ahead. Last week, markets were quite volatile again, with gold soaring to $4,550 and then retreating but finding support at $4,300. EUR/USD climbed above 1.18 while main indices closed the week higher at new records. The moves weren’t too big though, and we opened 35 trading signals in total, finishing the week with 28 winning signals and 9 losing ones. Although demand for safe haven assets is still high, gold fell precipitously from record highs following the Fed’s most recent rate cut comments, as profit-taking was prompted by Powell’s cautious tone. In December, gold jumped above $4.3800 following the Federal Reserve’s announcement of a 25 basis point rate decrease. But the impetus soon waned, and prices dropped back to $4,004. The 20 daily SMA (gray) held as support last week and buyers returned and pushed XAU above the $5,000 mark for the first time during Asian hours and extended the rally in New York, printing a fresh record high near $5,111 before retreating below $5,000 late in the session. But buyers returned and XAU climbed to $5,598 but pulled back below $5,000 again. Foreign exchange markets saw sharp swings. Early in the week, U.S. yield differentials and Japanese capital outflows pushed the dollar above ¥150, but disappointing U.S. jobs data triggered profit-taking, causing the USD/JPY to slide by four yen from its peak. However, the new BOJ governor the JPY has weakened and USD/JPY soared to 154 and we decided to close our buy signal for more than 80 pips as the pair found support at the 20 daily SMA (gray) and has rebounded more than 200 pips off that MA but reversed after the 25 bps rate cut from the FED. The price approached $160 but reversed after the BOJ meeting and fell 8 cents but found support at $152 at the 100 daily SMA (red) and rebounded above 156 but have reversed down again this week after the Japanese elections. Cryptocurrencies remained highly active over the summer. Bitcoin ( BTC ) climbed to fresh highs of $123,000 and $124,000 in July and August, supported by institutional inflows and technical strength. However, remarks from Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent ruling out U.S. increases to BTC reserves triggered a steep pullback, sending the coin down to $80K before finding support at the 100 weekly SMA (green). A rebound followed, sending BTC near $100 is the first major text for Bitcoin buyers. However BTC returned lower and fell below $80K, breaking below the but the 100 weekly SMA (green) but the decline stopped at the $60K support where the 200 weekly SM A(purpe) stands and rebounded above $70K. Ethereum ( ETH ) has been similarly strong, surging toward $4,800, its highest since 2021 and near its all-time peak of $4,860. Despite a dip last week, ETH found support at the 20-day SMA, with retail enthusiasm and renewed institutional participation driving fresh upside momentum. Last week we saw a dive below $2,000 but buyers returned n d pushed the price above $2K again.

title: A Promising Opening for Vanguard's International Real Estate Fund
content: Vanguard Global ex-U.S. Real Estate Index Fund ETF Shares US9220426764 The Vanguard Global ex-U.S. Real Estate ETF (VNQI) has entered the new year with considerable momentum. A combination of declining bond yields and a softer U.S. dollar is currently driving a notable revaluation of property markets outside the United States. This shift prompts the question of whether investors can now benefit from a lasting global trend reversal, following years of U.S. market dominance. Distinguishing itself through a strict geographic focus, the VNQI invests almost exclusively in real estate companies and REITs located outside American borders. Its portfolio is heavily diversified, holding 716 individual positions. Leading holdings include Australia's Goodman Group (3.65%), alongside Japanese giants Mitsui Fudosan (3.01%) and Mitsubishi Estate (2.72%), as well as Germany's Vonovia (2.34%). A key competitive advantage lies in its cost structure. With a total expense ratio (TER) of just 0.12%, it undercuts comparable products like the iShares Global REIT ETF (REET), which carries a 0.14% fee and includes U.S. holdings. While the REET distributes dividends quarterly, the VNQI follows an annual distribution schedule, yet currently offers the more attractive yield. The fundamentals for the real estate companies within the ETF have shown recent signs of stabilization. The price-to-book ratio (P/B) of its holdings has improved, climbing from 0.9 at the end of last year to a current level of 1.0. In February, the fund's dividend yield stood at a solid 4.27%. Furthermore, the inflation-linked indexing of rental contracts supports expectations for future dividend growth of approximately 3%. Essential VNQI metrics: * Dividend Yield: 4.27 % * Total Expense Ratio (TER): 0.12 % * Number of Holdings: 716 * Top Holding: Goodman Group (3.65 %) Should investors sell immediately? Or is it worth buying Vanguard Global ex-U.S. Real Estate Index Fund ETF Shares? Vanguard forecasts a long-term annual return potential of about 7.78% for this strategy. On Monday, the ETF's shares traded within a range of $50.08 to $50.65. The prospects for international real estate markets remain positive, as many securities continue to trade at a discount to their net asset values (NAV). Reduced interest rate volatility and stronger corporate balance sheets are enhancing earnings visibility for the remainder of the year. Looking further ahead, Vanguard identifies targeted opportunities in non-U.S. markets over the next five to ten years. While investments in artificial intelligence are primarily fueling growth in the United States, the resulting productivity gains are expected to increasingly benefit international sectors. For the VNQI, this environment highlights the combination of a stable dividend foundation and the potential for capital appreciation driven by a global recovery in property values. title: Perspective: Morning Commentary February 18
content: This morning commentary by StoneX provides an update on the financial markets as of February 18. It covers the positive movement in the Dow Jones Industrials, S&P, and NASDAQ, anticipation for the January Fed minutes, and movements in treasury yields and the U.S. dollar. The article also discusses crude oil prices and the grain market, noting geopolitical risks and concerns over global crop conditions, particularly for wheat and soybeans.
